text: Morning everyone im trying to access deposit and withdrawal info from various bf accounts. I was wondering the best way to do this. Ideally id like to pull through a list of the recent account transaction information excluding money placed on bets. What is the best way for me to do this? Iterating to test out different end points is taking about an hour an attempt due to things out of my control so was wondering if there is an already established best method. Any help is greatly appreciated Thanks

elements.text: Morning everyone im trying to access deposit and withdrawal info from various bf accounts. I was wondering the best way to do this. Ideally id like to pull through a list of the recent account transaction information excluding money placed on bets. What is the best way for me to do this? Iterating to test out different end points is taking about an hour an attempt due to things out of my control so was wondering if there is an already established best method. Any help is greatly appreciated Thanks

text: It sounds like you want <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/getAccountStatement>

text: If you're using bflw then make sure to use lightweight mode

elements.text: If you're using bflw then make sure to use lightweight mode

text: You can set the includeItem parameter to DEPOSITS_WITHDRAWALS to only get those items (i.e. exclude bets)

elements.text: You can set the includeItem parameter to DEPOSITS_WITHDRAWALS to only get those items (i.e. exclude bets)

text:
Quick question, I'm just using the following filter to get the best prices:
price_filter = betfairlightweight.filters.price_projection(
    price_data=['EX_BEST_OFFERS']
)

However, if I look on the site itself, they're not the best prices.
I take it, this is Betfairs Cross Matching offering the prices on the site ?

elements.text:

text: EX_BEST_OFFERS_DISP

elements.text: EX_BEST_OFFERS_DISP

text: Im looking at the runner_matched in the historic data.  I asked betfair about why sum runner matched =/= total matched and they asked me to provide example.  Could someone explain to me or point me to documentation to how the data we download from betfair historic works and how you calculate the total_matched and runner_matched from this data.

text:
So you interpret their tv for runners as the runner total_matched
```if "tv" in new_data:  # if runner removed tv: 0 is returned
                        runner.total_matched = new_data["tv"]```
but I think this is not what is in the data
```{"op":"mcm","clk":"5679370619","pt":1512304510680,"mc":[{"id":"1.137586726","rc":[{"atl":[[990,0],[1000,20.01],[1.11,5],[1.01,25175.33],[1.05,1078.63],[1.03,234.96]],"id":15431178},{"atb":[[340,18.26],[1.01,2473.49]],"id":12513676},{"trd":[[340,10]],"ltp":340.0,"tv":10.0,"id":12513676},{"atl":[[990,0]],"id":12513676}],"con":true,"img":false,"tv":584247.73}]}```
See here the total matched for the event is ~580,000 but the tv of the runner is just 10.
This event is 2017-12-03/1.137586726
I see similar sort of results elsewhere where it says runner_matched is often too small.
